text: Is Petzold, Cao and Gillespie from the mid 2000s still state of the art for tau leaping?

elements.text: Is Petzold, Cao and Gillespie from the mid 2000s still state of the art for tau leaping?

text: Tau-leaping method development seems stagnated to me. I’m not sure many people are thinking about it anymore, No one has given a good, performant solution to the issue of solutions going negative, so there are lots of adaptations of ODE and SDE methods (Runge-Kutta methods, Rock-methods, etc), but none of them have addressed the biggest limitation. In practice, I think the older Petzold methods are still the most popular, with much of the recent method development in the context of hybrid/multi-scale methods and coupling methods for variance reduction I think.

text: It's kind of what people use, but I'd put the Poisson Runge-Kutta stuff at the state of the art

elements.text: It's kind of what people use, but I'd put the Poisson Runge-Kutta stuff at the state of the art
